Signs: Sensitivity to change - They may get upset by minor changes or changes to their routine.
suggestions: Alerting to changes - Inform the student about upcoming changes in routine or activities in advance to prepare them

Signs: Sensitivity to change - They may get upset by minor changes or changes to their routine.
suggestions: Structured environment - Create a predictable classroom routine with visual schedules and clear expectations.

Signs: Difficulty initiating social interactions
suggestions: Social skills development - Incorporate structured social interaction activities to support communication and social skills

Signs: Difficulty initiating social interactions
suggestions: Teach social interaction skills like eye contact, turn-taking, and appropriate body language through role-playing and positive reinforcement.

Signs: Sensory hypersensitivity - They may have unusual reactions to how things smell, taste, look, feel, or sound.
suggestions: Sensory accommodations - Provide fidget toys, noise-cancelling headphones, or designated quiet spaces to manage sensory overload.

Signs: Sensory hypersensitivity - They may have unusual reactions to how things smell, taste, look, feel, or sound.
suggestions: Provide sensory tools like fidget toys, weighted blankets, or calming activities to manage sensory sensitivities.

Signs: Delayed speech or language development
suggestions: Use pictures, symbols, and visual cues to support communication and understanding.

Signs: Delayed speech or language development
suggestions: Use augmentative communication devices like picture communication boards if needed

Signs: Auditory Processing Disorder - challenges hearing small sound differences in words.
suggestions: Combine verbal and visual instruction with participatory activities

Signs: Auditory Processing Disorder - challenges hearing small sound differences in words.
suggestions: Provide copies of notes with simpler sentences (fewer clauses) and use graphic organizers

Signs: Dyscalculia - struggle with key concepts like bigger vs. smaller, doing basic math problems and/or more abstract math, spacial relations.
suggestions: Allow students to demonstrate their understanding through different formats like drawing, verbal explanations, or using manipulatives instead of only written tests.

Signs: Dyscalculia - struggle with key concepts like bigger vs. smaller, doing basic math problems and/or more abstract math, spacial relations.
suggestions: Incorporate different senses like touch, sight, and hearing to reinforce learning

Signs: Dysgraphia - challenge with handwriting, which can interfere with learning to spell words in writing and speed of writing text
suggestions: Activities like playing with clay or tracing letters can help strengthen hand muscles

Signs: Dysgraphia - challenge with handwriting, which can interfere with learning to spell words in writing and speed of writing text
suggestions: Use paper with raised or different-colored lines to help form letters and use graph paper to help line up math problems

Signs: Dyslexia - challenges in understanding and working with language– including phonemic awareness and phonics
suggestions: Repeat directions in multiple ways and use step-by-step instructions

Signs: Dyslexia - challenges in understanding and working with language– including phonemic awareness and phonics
suggestions: Combine verbal and visual instruction with participatory activities

Signs: Language Processing Disorder - difference in how the brain processes spoken or written language, rather than the physical ability to hear or speak; challenge with comprehending the meaning of words, sentences, and narratives due to difficulty processing information received.
suggestions: Use drawings, photos, and gestures to support spoken lessons

Signs: Language Processing Disorder - difference in how the brain processes spoken or written language, rather than the physical ability to hear or speak; challenge with comprehending the meaning of words, sentences, and narratives due to difficulty processing information received.
suggestions: Use "chunking" to give simple directions with key words and repeat key information and rephrase as needed

Signs: Anxiety - Having angry outbursts
suggestions: Check-in with students regularly to assess their emotional state.

Signs: Anxiety - Having angry outbursts
suggestions: Establish Predictable Routines - Consistent routines provide a sense of security.

Signs: Anxiety - Withdrawing and not wanting to do things they used to enjoy
suggestions: Validate their feelings and concerns.

Signs: Anxiety - Withdrawing and not wanting to do things they used to enjoy
suggestions: Help students break down large tasks into smaller, manageable steps.

Signs: Anxiety - Having difficulty with daily functioning and activities
suggestions: Provide Accommodations - Offer flexible deadlines and extended time for assignments.

Signs: Anxiety - Having difficulty with daily functioning and activities
suggestions: Create opportunities for students to connect with you and their peers.

Signs: Anxiety - Lacking confidence to try new things
suggestions: Make a habit of using positive affirmations with all of your students.

Signs: Anxiety - Lacking confidence to try new things
suggestions: Offer opportunities for students to communicate their needs privately.

Signs: Anxiety - Constantly worrying about academic performance, social situations, or future events.
suggestions: Refer students for professional help when necessary.

Signs: Anxiety - Constantly worrying about academic performance, social situations, or future events.
suggestions: Understand how anxiety can impact a student's learning and behavior.

Signs: Depression - Behavior changes - Acting out, being unmotivated, or becoming more isolated
suggestions: Avoid judgmental or dismissive statements.

Signs: Depression - Behavior changes - Acting out, being unmotivated, or becoming more isolated
suggestions: Teach stress-management techniques.

Signs: Depression - Feeling worthless, guilty, or empty, or having thoughts of suicide
suggestions: Immediately contact a school counselor, mental health professional, or crisis hotline.

Signs: Depression - Feeling worthless, guilty, or empty, or having thoughts of suicide
suggestions: Respect confidentiality (within legal and ethical limits).

Signs: Depression - Difficulty completing assignments
suggestions: Speak to teachers about potential accommodations like extra time on assignments or reduced workload

Signs: Depression - Difficulty completing assignments
suggestions: Break down large tasks into smaller steps.

Signs: Depression - Irritability or increased anger.
suggestions: Promote mindfulness and relaxation techniques.

Signs: Depression - Irritability or increased anger.
suggestions: Practice active listening.

Signs: Depression - Social changes - Withdrawing from friends and family, or losing interest in activities they used to enjoy
suggestions: Connect students with school counselors, psychologists, or social workers.

Signs: Depression - Social changes - Withdrawing from friends and family, or losing interest in activities they used to enjoy
suggestions: Encourage physical activity, healthy eating, and sufficient sleep.

Signs: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder - Doubts about whether they have completed tasks, like locking doors, or turning off appliances.
suggestions: Be aware that symptoms may not always be visible.

Signs: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder - Doubts about whether they have completed tasks, like locking doors, or turning off appliances.
suggestions: Maintain consistent routines and schedules.

Signs: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder - Concerns about accidentally hurting themselves or others.
suggestions: With the student's and parents' consent, provide age-appropriate education about OCD.

Signs: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder - Concerns about accidentally hurting themselves or others.
suggestions: Avoid reinforcing compulsions - Do not provide excessive reassurance.

Signs: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder - Unwanted and disturbing thoughts, images, or urges, which can include violent or sexual themes.
suggestions: Do not provide excessive reassurance.

Signs: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder - Unwanted and disturbing thoughts, images, or urges, which can include violent or sexual themes.
suggestions: Allow students to use coping mechanisms, such as deep breathing or mindfulness techniques.

Signs: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder - Feeling that things must be "just right" or perfectly aligned.
suggestions: Work with the student's therapist to implement strategies for managing compulsions.

Signs: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder - Feeling that things must be "just right" or perfectly aligned.
suggestions: Understand that OCD is a neurological disorder, not a choice.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Frequent anger, resentment, and temper tantrums
suggestions: Behavioral health professional, such as a therapist, can help the child learn to manage anger and impulses

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Frequent anger, resentment, and temper tantrums
suggestions: Develop an individualized education plan (IEP) or 504 plan to address the student's specific needs.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Mean or hateful speech when upset
suggestions: Focus on positive interactions and avoid power struggles.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Mean or hateful speech when upset
suggestions: Establish a safe space where the student can calm down when needed.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Blaming others for mistakes
suggestions: Focus on rewarding positive behaviors rather than punishing negative ones.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Blaming others for mistakes
suggestions: Offer choices whenever possible to give the student a sense of control.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Refusing to obey rules
suggestions: Provide clear, concise instructions and rules.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Refusing to obey rules
suggestions: Communicate expectations in a calm, firm, and respectful manner.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Being easily annoyed or touchy
suggestions: Avoid escalating conflicts. Stay calm and speak in a low, even tone.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Being easily annoyed or touchy
suggestions: Establish a safe space where the student can calm down when needed.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Persistent pattern of angry, irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, and vindictiveness.
suggestions: Positive reinforcement - Actively praise appropriate behaviors and efforts to encourage positive actions.

Signs: Oppossitional Defiant Disorder (ODD) - Persistent pattern of angry, irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, and vindictiveness.
suggestions: Positive reinforcement - Actively praise appropriate behaviors and efforts to encourage positive actions.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Inattention - Difficulty sustaining attention in tasks or play.
suggestions: Provide clear, predictable routines and transitions.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Inattention -  Difficulty sustaining attention in tasks or play.
suggestions: Break down complex tasks into smaller, manageable steps.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Inattention - Being easily distracted by extraneous stimuli.
suggestions: Seat the student in a quiet area of the classroom, away from windows and high-traffic areas.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Inattention - Being easily distracted by extraneous stimuli.
suggestions: Reduce visual clutter in the classroom.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Hyperactivity - Fidgeting or squirming in their seat.
suggestions: Allow for frequent breaks and opportunities for movement.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Hyperactivity - Fidgeting or squirming in their seat.
suggestions: Seat the student in a location that minimizes distractions.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Hyperactivity - Difficulty playing or engaging in leisure activities quietly.
suggestions: Allow the use of fidget tools, such as stress balls or fidget spinners (when used appropriately).

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Hyperactivity - Difficulty playing or engaging in leisure activities quietly.
suggestions: Incorporate physical activity into lessons.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Academic Challenges - Incomplete assignments.
suggestions: Allow extra time for tests and assignments.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Academic Challenges - Incomplete assignments.
suggestions: Break down assignments into smaller, more manageable tasks.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Academic Challenges - Poor test performance despite apparent understanding.
suggestions: Provide access to assistive technology, such as audio recorders or text-to-speech software.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Academic Challenges - Poor test performance despite apparent understanding.
suggestions: Reduce the number of questions or problems on assignments.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Academic Challenges - Difficulty with organization and time management.
suggestions: Teach organizational skills, such as using planners, checklists, and color-coding systems.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Academic Challenges - Difficulty with organization and time management.
suggestions: Help students organize their desks and materials.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Academic Challenges - Social Difficulties - Difficulty following social rules.
suggestions: Focus on praising positive behaviors and effort.

Signs: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) - Academic Challenges - Social Difficulties - Difficulty following social rules.
suggestions: Use a reward system to motivate desired behaviors.No file uploaded
column8: Teaching kids how to eat veggies
